questions.question: What is a process in Linux?
choices: A file on the hard drive
An instance of a running program
questions.answer: An instance of a running program

questions.question: Which command provides a snapshot of current processes?
What does PID stand for?
Which PID is always assigned to the init process?
What command provides a real-time, dynamic view of system processes?
Which of the following is NOT a process state in Linux?
What command is used to list current jobs associated with the terminal?
Which command moves a suspended foreground process to the background?
What does the 'nice' command do?
choices: Starts a process with modified scheduling priority
Sends a friendly message to another user
questions.answer: Starts a process with modified scheduling priority

questions.question: What is a zombie process?
choices: A process that consumes a lot of CPU
A process that has completed execution but still has an entry in the process table
A process that runs at night
A process that infects other processes
questions.answer: A process that has completed execution but still has an entry in the process table

questions.question: Which command is an enhanced alternative to 'top'?
What does PPID stand for?
Which command is used to change the priority of a running process?
What is the default update interval for the 'top' command?
Which symbol is used to run a command in the background?
What is the range of nice values in Linux?
Which command brings a background process to the foreground?
What does UID represent in process attributes?
Which option for 'ps' shows all processes for all users?
What type of process has control of the terminal?
Which key is typically used to quit the 'top' command?
What does a lower nice value indicate?
Which filesystem in Linux provides information about processes?
What command can be used to kill a process from within 'top'?
Which state is a process in when it's waiting for a resource or event?
What does the 'ps -ef' command do?
choices: Provides a full-format listing of processes
questions.answer: Provides a full-format listing of processes

questions.question: Which feature of 'htop' is not available in 'top'?
What is the purpose of job control in Linux?
choices: To manage foreground and background processes
To schedule jobs for later execution
To assign jobs to specific users
questions.answer: To manage foreground and background processes

questions.question: Which command shows processes for a specific user?
What is the default nice value for processes in Linux?
